title: Between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018, will an armed group from Turkey engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Turkey?
preds: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Integer nec odio. Praesent libero. Sed cursus ante dapibus diam. Sed nisi. Nulla quis sem at nibh elementum imperdiet. An influx of refugees coupled with domestic crackdowns and purges of dissident civilians and ongoing and escalating fighting between government forces and Kurdish groups inside and along the Turkish border could lead to 1000+ deaths within a year

Dateline 3-14-2018 NKARA, Turkey — The 2017 annual report of the Turkish Interior Ministry, released in late February, raised fresh questions about a controversy ongoing since the failed coup attempt on July 15, 2016. According to the report, 2,198,774 individuals lost their vehicle registrations, gun licenses, driver's licenses and professional IDs last year, while 106,740 guns were recorded as either lost or stolen. News of the huge number of missing weapons comes amid concerns over the reported proliferation of unlicensed guns, including through online sales, and has reignited debate on weapons that were reported missing from military and police armories in the wake of the coup attempt. In its 2014 report, the Interior Ministry had put the number of lost or stolen guns at 14,682, while the number of lost or stolen license plates stood at only 3,037. In its 2015 report, the number of lost or stolen guns increased more than 500% to 91,120, while the number of lost or stolen license plates hit 703,749. In the report for 2016, the year of the coup attempt, lost or stolen guns further increased, to 107,628, while lost or stolen license plates shot up to 900,383. During the night of the attempted putsch, civilians who took to the streets to stop the putschists seized some soldiers' weapons, while some soldiers surrendered and voluntarily handed them over. Meanwhile, there have also been reports that weapons were distributed to civilians from police warehouses.
 -- https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2018/03/turkey-mystery-lingers-over-missing-weapons.html
A thousand Kurds and Christians maybe.

Dateline 3-10-2018  2018 started as a fairly calm year for Turkey; reported fatality numbers were low and trends suggested they may continue falling. However, since February, there has been a dramatic spike in the number of reported fatalities.... The turning point occurred during the week of February 18 in particular; the highest weekly fatality total this year was reported that week. Almost all of these fatalities are reported in the provinces located along the Iraqi border, Sirnak and Hakkari. The majority of these events involve clashes between Turkish security forces and the Kurdistan Workers’ Party (PKK). -- https://www.acleddata.com/2018/03/08/fatalities-in-turkey/

While tensions between Turkish forces and Kurdish militia groups are high and Erdoğan's rhetoric sympathetic to Islamists Turkey probably won't be willing to do anything that would result in being ejected from NATO and souring trade with Europe.
Turkey has a divided populace regarding the government but it has largely been peaceful protest so little chance of violence

Since the beginning of the year, Turkey has turned its attention from Kurds in Turkey to the conflict in Syria. However, the Kurdish issue continues to be a strong issue on President Erdogan's mind. If the issue returns to the surface this year, Erdogan has shown his willingness to target Kurdish forces which could lead to civilian casualties amongst Kurdish populations.
It is an ongoing event where the state targets Kurds within Turkey.
Turkey is involved in several risky areas with the PKK as well as Syrian separatists, so while hundreds may be killed during 2018, 1,000 is a high bare for any one group to achieve.

Government-sponsored violence will continue and possibly intensify with the ending of hostilities in Syria and a refocusing of Kurdish and progressive Turkish elements demanding radical action on the part of the Erdogan regime -- which will not budge.  Killing may take place in penal institutions as well as in the field.
Incident of 9 Feb involving Kurds is likely to increase tensions and Turks will feel pressure to do something.
The situation in Turkey seems to be under control so the chance of this even to occur is low.
If the Kurds opt to use this technique it will be to their own detriment, with the potential to cause issues in NATO. I tend to think it unlikely, though not impossible.

Turkey is rather image-conscious. Despite some moves towards a more totalitarian government, they are still a democracy and have to be conscious of the avoidance of civilian deaths not only to the international community, but towards their own people. Due to the number of conflicts they are currently involved in, there is a small chance that escalation with the PKK or other similar groups could lead towards a systematic targeting of Kurds, most likely just outside their borders in one of the conflict zones. The other population that could be potentially targeted would be Syrians, most likely during an incursion into a bordering Syrian town in an effort to achieve their military or political goals. The 1% chance I've assigned is due to these conflicts, but Turkey would have a lot to lose by undertaking such a campaign and there is not much to gain. While their history is unfortunate for the tragic genocide they unleashed during nation building, history is unlikely to repeat itself within this short timeframe.

The ongoing anti-Kurdish war-front seems to be focusing on Syria for the time-being, though there's always the worrisome possibility that an increasingly Islamic-nationalist government (which once was a secular bastion of the middle-east) will simply decide to start exterminating people.  I have a tendency to think it's unlikely for Turkey to go down the dark path in 2018, but I'm linking a couple articles that seem to be emerging warning signs. EU Worried about Erosion of Rule of Law:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/eu-worried-about-erosion-of-rule-of-law-in-turkey/2018/02/02/a47d37b6-081c-11e8-aa61-f3391373867e_story.html?utm_term=.b84774b13051 Turkey Bombs Syrian Kurds:
https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/01/middleeast/syria-kurds-assault-civilians-intl/index.html
Unlikely as Europe might step in
If this were to occur it would most likely be against the Kurds, but given ongoing conflict it would be difficult to verify.

Sticking to 5%. Sultan Edrogan has an election in 18 months. He will want to establish some “safe” zones at expense of Syria and continue internal purges while continuing to reduce secularism and try to avoid any big blow ups with the Kurds. He will have the blood of hundreds, potentially thousands on his hands (mostly outside Turkey) but the reality is he’ll try to improve economy etc. That takes a while to filter through the economy - to ensure he is once more elected and gets to stay in his palace. The Kurds are going to lay low while they get pummelled and wait for their time (no more plebiscites ok guys?).

Erdogan is favourably inclined to killing people, but he doesn't seem to care who they are and he's not necessarily in any hurry.  Sooner or later he will get back to killing Kurds, but he may not make these numbers by this deadline.

Dateline 1-23-2018 Special “conquest” prayers were held in all of Turkey’s 90,000 mosques over the weekend to lend support to the government’s recently launched military offensive into Syria. Once a bastion of state-enforced secularism, Turkey under Erdogan has embraced a new Islamic nationalism.  -- "Signal, GZERO Media" <signal=eurasiagroup.net@mail136.sea22.mcdlv.net>

The Afrin campaign is an extension of Turkey's internal fatal conflicts with its Kurdish citizens. Dateline 1-22-2018 Turkey has been battling armed Kurdish fighters for decades in the southeastern part of the country. Among those groups Ankara is fighting is the Kurdistan Workers Party, or PKK, which had separatist roots, and later pushed for more autonomy from the Turkish central government. The violence has left 40,000 thousand civilians, soldiers and armed fighters dead, costing the country hundreds of billions of dollars. Turkey considers the PKK a "terrorist organisation", and sees the armed Syrian Kurdish groups as an extension of the PKK. Justifying the military operation, President Erdogan said the PKK and the Syrian Kurdish group "are all the same", and changing their names "does not change the fact that they are terror organisations".  -- http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/01/turkey-operation-syria-afrin-key-players-180121060919195.html

Dateline 1-21-2018 The Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, vowed on Sunday that the campaign would be over in a “short time” and warned Kurdish political activists in Turkey against staging protests. “This is a national struggle,” he told a rally in Bursa. “We will crush anyone who opposes our national struggle.” Turkey said it was launching the Afrin campaign to clear out the People’s Protection Units (YPG) and its political arm, the Democratic Union party (PYD), from the district. Ankara regards them as part of the Syrian wing of the Kurdistan Workers’ party (PKK), a designated terror group that has fought a decades-long insurgency against the Turkish state. -- https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/21/turkey-starts-ground-incursion-into-kurdish-controlled-afrin-in-syria
The YPG and other Kurd organizations are proclaiming in the twitesphere that this is happening and that Turkey is setting them up[ for bame to justify the Afrin Campaign.
So if Turkey captures Afrin and kills a 1,ooo souls and annexes it, would it count? How bout if they just declare it a buffer zone or some such?
Increasing to 5% given Sultan Erdogan’s Sabre rattling with Kurds (with Tsar Vlad the shirtless ok).

It is not difficult to imagine Erdogan sitting on a tuffet, blowing his Kurds away.   Whatever a tuffet is.  However, the definition for all of these questions is pretty restrictive, so he'll have to do it just right to get a Yes resolution.

Today, Turkey has begun a major move against the Kurd-held enclave in northern Syria. Next up, ethnic cleansing within Turkey? Dateline 1-19-2018 The Syrian Kurdish YPG militia has said Turkish forces have fired about 70 shells at Kurdish villages in the Afrin region of north-western Syria, as Ankara said its threatened military assault was “de facto” under way. The bombardment from Turkish territory began at around midnight and continued into Friday morning. Turkey considers the Syrian Kurdish militia as an extension of Kurdish rebels fighting Turkey and has vowed to attack their Afrin enclave, massing troops and tanks on its border for several days. Military action, however, risks further inflaming relations with the US, which allied with the Kurdish-led Syrian Defence Force in its campaign against Islamic State. The Turkish defence minister, Nurettin Canikli, on Friday said the assault had begun. “The operation has actually started de facto with cross-border shelling,” Canikli told the broadcaster A Haber. “When I say ‘de facto’, I don’t want it to be misunderstood. It has begun. All terror networks and elements in northern Syria will be eliminated. There is no other way.” https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/jan/19/turkey-begins-assault-kurdish-enclave-in-syria
They will kill Kurds, but beliw that number In Turkey. Syria is another equation.

The P(A|B) for the PKK and related insurgent group attacks stand at .1.  The event involved in a single fatality in an attack using irregular tactics (an explosion of a guided missile on a Turkish military base) in Hakkari Province on Jan 14, 2018.
I think there is a small probability Turkey could go after Kurds.
Nope. Erdogan has a tight grip on things.

Erdogan is trying to make constitutional chamges within turkey so it becomes more islamic rather than liberal. Problem is to build the economy of the future you need science and education, not religious indoctrination. If erdogan shifts turkey to an unstable form of governence. The economy will slow in growth and unemployment, financial instability might rise. Leading to civil strife. Deaths may occur while the government tries to stop change of course

The current government's hold on power makes a large scale conflict unlikely. Barring all out war with external Kurdish groups, I would expect minor terrorist attacks and widespread political oppression by the government but not armed conflict.
Dictator Erdogan unlikely to cause/allow deaths at home - more likely to stir it up elsewhere. Unless the Kurds rise up...

This depends very strongly from 2 factors:
1) Will the civil war in Syria and the turkish engagement therein end?
2) Will the turkish military and/or the turkish government accept areas controlled by the Kurds at its borders?
If 1) is answered with "Yes" or 2) is answered with "No" there will be a quick escalation of violence, because president Erdogan needs an external enemy aside from the US, the EU or Germany to stabilize his position and not to harm any further his most important economic relations. And if Turkey starts a fight with the Kurds outside its borders there is no doubt that the Kurds within the borders of Turkey also will start a fight - a bloody one.

President Erdogan currently seems to be firmly in control of the state forces of coercion.  I think this control might get shaky in the following year but nowhere near enough to allow a campaign that kills 1000 civilians.
Turkish forces are poised to attack Kurdish areas with the slightest provocation.
THE CURRENT LEADERSHIP OF TURKEY HAVE AN IRON GRIP ON TURKEY.
Trump told Erdogan in a phone call that the U.S. would cease the supply of arms to the Kurds fighting ISIS in Syria.
Highly likely given the instability that has fomented since the 2016 coup.
Turkey wants to be stable. They will avoid the conflicts such as those Syria and Iraq had to endure.

Even in the botched coup attempt, there were only 275 deaths.   Turks, having been through this near brush with civil war, and having seen its neighbors Iraq and Syria destroyed by violent triabalism, are going to studiously avoid extremism, and pursue a gradual relaxation of paranoia while defending Constitutional processes.
To stir unrest for the government of ardogan.

Turkey's police state apparatus is sufficiently strong (and loyal to Erdogan) to quash any groups conducting anti-government violence in 2018, well before such groups would be able to implement a systematic campaign of killing Turkish civilians in the hundreds or even dozens.  Its remotely possible, on the other hand, that the Turkish government would not act to prevent (or indeed might even indirectly support) systematic killing of Kurds in southeast Turkey, though such a campaign would prompt intense international pressure against the government.

The Turkish government is becoming more hardline. I think that if the Kurdish people form a state that includes parts of turkey the Turkish may send it's military in to secure it's sovereignty. This could lead to large scale civilian casualties.
